abstract.t: This document specifies conventions for including stable author identifiers in Internet-Drafts and RFCs using the RFCXML v3 format. Because email addresses and organizational affiliations can change over time, documents benefit from a stable, globally unique, dereferenceable identifier for each author. As a pragmatic first step, this document defines a profile that uses ORCID iDs in the existing <uri> element of the <author> address block. It also discusses limitations of ORCID-specific identifiers and sketches options for a future provider-independent approach.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Long-term discoverability, attribution, and disambiguation of authors are important for the archival value of Internet-Drafts (I-Ds) and RFCs. Today, author identity is primarily expressed using names and email addresses in RFCXML. However, names can be non-unique or change over time, and email addresses frequently become invalid. This document defines a simple convention to add a stable author identifier to each author entry, without requiring changes to the RFCXML schema or publication tools.

The convention leverages ORCID iDs () as stable person identifiers and places the canonical ORCID HTTPS URI in the existing <> element within the <address> of the <author>. This yields immediate benefits for disambiguation and metadata linking while remaining backward compatible with existing tooling and renderers.

section.title: Goals and Non-Goals
section.t: Goals:

ul.li: Provide a stable, globally unique author identifier that complements names and email.
Use only existing RFCXML v3 elements; avoid schema or pipeline changes.
Enable straightforward consumption by tooling (xml2rfc, bibliographic exporters, indexes).
Remain optional and privacy-aware; authors may opt out.

section.t: Non-Goals:

ul.li: Mandate a specific identity provider forever. ORCID is a pragmatic first step.
Replace author names or emails. This convention complements existing fields.

section.title: Terminology and Conventions
section.t: The key words MUST, MUST NOT, SHOULD, SHOULD NOT, and MAY in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Specification: Stable Author IDs in RFCXML

ol.li: Per the RFCXML v3 schema, at most one <uri> is allowed inside <address>. This specification reserves that single <uri> for the author's stable identifier (e.g., an ORCID iD).
If an author has a stable person identifier (e.g., an ORCID iD), the author entry SHOULD include it as a URI in the sole <uri> child of the <address> element.
When using an ORCID iD, the value MUST be the canonical HTTPS form https://orcid.org/NNNN-NNNN-NNNN-NNNN, where the last character MAY be an X per ORCID’s checksum format.
Editors and tooling SHOULD verify that the ORCID URI resolves and that the displayed name on the ORCID record matches the author to a reasonable degree.
Including a stable identifier is optional. Authors who do not wish to publish such an identifier MAY omit it.

section.title: ORCID-Based Pragmatic Profile
section.t: This document defines an initial, provider-specific profile that uses ORCID iDs as the stable author identifier. The canonical form is an HTTPS URI with the authority orcid.org and a path consisting of four groups of four digits separated by hyphens, optionally ending with an X. Example: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097.

The ORCID URI is placed as the first <uri> element under <address>. Renderers that implement this convention can treat the first <uri> as the stable author ID, and may decorate it with an ORCID glyph or label when the URI host is orcid.org.
Documents that include multiple authors repeat this convention for each <author>.

section.title: Examples
section.t: Minimum example using only the stable ID:
section.sourcecode: <author fullname="Ada Lovelace" initials="A." surname="Lovelace"> <organization>Analytical Engines Ltd.</organization> <address> <email>ada@example.net</email> <uri>https://orcid.org/0000-0001-2345-678X</uri> </address> </author>
section.t: Including a homepage pragmatically (outside <address>):
section.sourcecode: <section anchor="author-urls" title="Additional Author URLs" numbered="false"> <dl> <dt>Ada Lovelace</dt> <dd>Homepage: <eref target="https://www.example.net/~ada/"/></dd> </dl> </section>
section.t: Alternative using <contact> in an appendix (maps name to a single extra URI each):
section.sourcecode: <section anchor="author-contacts" title="Author Contacts (Additional Links)" numbered="false"> <contact fullname="Ada Lovelace"> <address> <email>ada@example.net</email> <uri>https://www.example.net/~ada/</uri> <!-- homepage here; ORCID stays in author/address --> </address> </contact> </section>

ul.li: Reserve the single <uri> within <address> for the stable author ID. Do not add additional <uri> elements there.

li.t: To expose additional author URLs (homepages, profiles), prefer one of:

ul.li: A short unnumbered section (e.g., “Additional Author URLs”) using <dl>/<dt>/<dd> with <eref> links.
An appendix listing <contact> blocks, each with an <address> whose sole <uri> is the homepage.
xml2rfc and similar tools SHOULD preserve ordering of elements and avoid reordering.

section.title: Compatibility and Rendering
section.t: This convention requires no changes to the RFCXML v3 vocabulary (). Existing renderers that ignore additional <uri> elements will continue to produce valid output. Renderers that wish to surface stable author IDs can choose to display the first <uri> with an appropriate label or icon.

ul.li: Provider Dependence: ORCID is an external service; availability and policies are outside the IETF stream’s control.
Coverage: Not all contributors have ORCID iDs, and some may decline to maintain one.
Record Accuracy: Although ORCID supports verification, some records may be sparse or out of date. Editors SHOULD confirm that the ORCID appears to correspond to the author.
Linkability and Privacy: Publishing a stable identifier can ease cross-site linking of an individual’s activity. Authors SHOULD be informed and MAY opt out.

Multiple Profiles / Mergers: Rarely, authors may have multiple ORCID records or merge records over time. The canonical HTTPS URI SHOULD be used, and updates handled in subsequent document revisions as needed.

section.title: Toward Provider-Independent Stable IDs and RFCXML Evolution (Non‑Normative)
Provider-Independent Options
section.t: To avoid dependence on a single identity provider, the community may consider a future, provider-independent mechanism. Potential options include (non-exhaustive):

ul.li: Typed URIs in RFCXML: Extend RFCXML to allow a dedicated, typed <author-id> element with a type attribute (e.g., type="orcid", type="did", type="acct"), enabling unambiguous interpretation without relying on position.
Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs): Support did: URIs that resolve to signed DID Documents (), allowing cryptographic proof of control.
acct: URIs with WebFinger: Support acct:user@example.com with WebFinger discovery () for provider neutrality while remaining email-adjacent.
Multiple IDs with Preference: Allow multiple identifiers (e.g., ORCID and DID) with an explicit preference or priority indicator.

Verification Hooks: Define optional verification metadata (e.g., proof-of-possession via OAuth/OpenID Connect or signed statements) for stronger binding between the document author and the identifier.

section.title: Potential RFCXML Evolution (Allow Multiple URIs with Semantics)
section.t: This document proposes an evolution path for RFCXML in which <address> may contain multiple <uri> elements, and where <uri> carries a lightweight attribute to indicate the intended semantics. This avoids overloading positional conventions and enables tools to reliably distinguish a stable author identifier from other links.

t.strong: Sketch of changes (Relax NG Compact, illustrative only):
Example (future-compatible, not valid in RFCXML v3):

section.sourcecode: <author fullname="Ada Lovelace" initials="A." surname="Lovelace"> <organization>Analytical Engines Ltd.</organization> <address> <email>ada@example.net</email> <uri type="authorid" scheme="orcid">https://orcid.org/0000-0001-2345-678X</uri> <uri type="homepage">https://www.example.net/~ada/</uri> <uri type="profile" scheme="github">https://github.com/ada</uri> </address> </author>
section.t: Backwards compatibility: Existing RFCXML v3 documents remain valid. Renderers that ignore the new attributes still display clickable links. Tools that understand the type attribute can reliably find the author’s stable identifier (type="authorid") without depending on element order.

section.title: Privacy Considerations
section.t: Stable identifiers increase the ease of correlating activity across venues. Working groups and editors SHOULD inform authors about this implication. Publishing an identifier is optional, and authors MAY omit or remove identifiers at their discretion in subsequent revisions.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The main security consideration is misbinding—associating an identifier with the wrong person. Editors and tools SHOULD perform basic validation (e.g., dereferencing the URI and comparing displayed names) and avoid accepting identifiers that resolve to error pages or clearly unrelated records. Typosquatting domains (e.g., lookalike hostnames) should be avoided.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document has no IANA actions.

section.title: Acknowledgments
section.t: Thanks to Carsten Bormann for bringing up the idea and to Colin Perkins, Lixia Zhang and other IRSG members for their contributions to the discussion.

section.title: Appendix A: RFCXML Evolution Ideas (Non‑Normative)
section.t: This appendix consolidates potential schema evolutions discussed in the body of this document so they can be referenced independently. These proposals are non‑normative and target a future revision of RFCXML. Current RFCXML v3 remains the normative basis of this document.

section.title: A.1 Allow Multiple URIs in <address> with Semantics
section.t: Permit multiple <uri> elements within <address>, each carrying a lightweight type attribute that indicates semantics (e.g., authorid, homepage, profile, other). An optional scheme attribute can hint at the identifier system (e.g., orcid, did, isni).

Interoperability guidance: Tools should treat exactly one uri[@type='authorid'] as the stable identifier for de‑duplication and linking. Other URIs are optional metadata. Renderers that lack support for the new attributes should still display URIs as links, preserving backward compatibility.

t.strong: Future-style example (not valid in RFCXML v3):

section.sourcecode: <author fullname="Ada Lovelace" initials="A." surname="Lovelace"> <organization>Analytical Engines Ltd.</organization> <address> <email>ada@example.net</email> <uri type="authorid" scheme="orcid">https://orcid.org/0000-0001-2345-678X</uri> <uri type="homepage">https://www.example.net/~ada/</uri> <uri type="profile" scheme="github">https://github.com/ada</uri> </address> </author>

section.title: A.2 Dedicated <author-id> Element
section.t: Introduce a distinct <author-id> element under <author> to carry one or more identifiers without overloading <address>. The element can have a type attribute (e.g., orcid, did, isni) and contain the canonical URI as text.
This keeps contact coordinates (<address>) separate from persistent identifiers and supports multiple IDs by design.

ul.li: DID: Permit did: URIs and define best practices for referencing canonical forms.
acct: Allow acct:user@example.com URIs and discovery via WebFinger.
Multiple IDs: Allow multiple identifiers per author with an explicit priority indicator.
Verification hooks: Optional metadata or workflows to verify control of the referenced identifier.
Define a default mapping from RFCXML v3 (single <address>/<uri>) to the future model (e.g., become uri[@type='authorid'] or an <author-id type='…'> entry).
Encourage renderers to surface the stable author identifier distinctly (icon/label) while listing other links separately.
Maintain strict backward compatibility: documents written for v3 remain valid and renderable.
